title: Rotational inertia - compare irregular objects ABC

content.question: Three solid objects of equal mass, <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math>, <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math>, and <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>C</mtext></math>, each hang from a pivot at the top end of the object, as shown in the figure. Object <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math> has its center of mass (<math alttext="C O M" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>COM</mi></math>) located midway between the top and bottom ends. Object <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math> has its <math alttext="C O M" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>COM</mi></math> located closer to the bottom end. Object <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>C</mtext></math> is identical to Object <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math>, except that it is hung upside-down and so its <math alttext="C O M" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>COM</mi></math> is closer to the top end. Which object(s) has (have) the greatest rotational inertia about the pivot?

choices.label: Objects <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math> and <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>C</mtext></math>

skill.text: 3.B: Apply an appropriate law, definition, theoretical relationship, or model to make a claim.
